channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Kolkata Testifies to the Grace of Mother Teresa, Its New Saint
item.media:description: Nuns from the Missionaries of Charity in Kolkata, India, watched a live broadcast of the canonization ceremony of Mother Teresa on Sunday.
item.description: In an Indian city that has expressed ambivalence about the work of a missionary who made it her home, praise carried the day of her canonization by Pope Francis.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: In Philippine Drug War, Little Help for Those Who Surrender
item.media:description: Manila residents in a Zumba class. Many turned themselves in for drug abuse, but such workouts are often the extent of the help they receive.
item.media:credit: Nacho Hernandez for The New York Times
item.description: An estimated 687,000 drug users have turned themselves in since President Rodrigo Duterte took office, but the government is proving unprepared to assist them.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Bombings at Afghan Defense Ministry Kill at Least 20 in Kabul
item.description: The coordinated attack in a crowded neighborhood was blamed on the Taliban, and an army general and a police security chief were reported among the dead.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL and JAWAD SUKHANYAR

item.title: Vote in Hong Kong Deepens a Thorn in China’s Side
item.media:description: Nathan Law, right, and supporters celebrating on Monday after he won a seat on the Legislative Council in Hong Kong. He was a leader of the protests that closed major thoroughfares in 2014.
item.description: The election of six freethinking young legislators means that Beijing must deal with an indigenous movement elevated to positions of political power.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: ‘I’ve Become a Racist’: Migrant Wave Unleashes Danish Tensions Over Identity
item.media:description: A bus stop in Norrebro, a multicultural neighborhood in Copenhagen. More than 36,000 asylum seekers, mostly Muslims, have poured into Denmark over the past two years.
item.media:credit: Ilvy Njiokiktjien for The New York Times
item.description: The thousands of Muslim asylum seekers pouring into Denmark have spawned a backlash, and questions over whether the country has a latent racial hostility at its core.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ZUCCHINO
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Mother Teresa Is Made a Saint by Pope Francis
item.media:description: A nun belonging to the Missionaries of Charity carrying one of Mother Teresa’s relics to the canonization ceremony in St. Peter’s Square on Sunday.
item.description: The canonization on Sunday morning honors a lifetime working with “the poorest of the poor,” first in the slums of Kolkata, India, and then in other parts of the world.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETTA POVOLEDO

item.title: ‘Braconid’ Wins the Day and the World Scrabble Championship 2016
item.media:description: Brett Smitheram during the final game of the World Scrabble Championship 2016 against Mark Nyman in Lille, France, on Sunday.
item.description: Good for 176 points, the word for a type of parasitic wasp helped a London recruitment consultant take the top prize of 7,000 euros.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Egypt’s Christians Say They Are at a ‘Breaking Point’
item.media:description: A Mass for Coptic Christians in Ismailia, Egypt, on July 24 at the site of a chapel that was burned during clashes in the city.
item.description: While Imam Mahmoud Gomaa, appointed to keep the peace between two faiths, blames journalists for exaggerating the problem, a local bishop says, “We are at a breaking point.”
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Political Intrigue in Israel Leaves Commuters Without Trains for a Day
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel and Transportation Minister Yisrael Katz, left, during a cabinet meeting in Jerusalem on Sunday.
item.description: An uproar followed a shutdown that appeared to be related to unholy bickering and muscle flexing inside the fractious government.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Memo From South Africa: A.N.C.’s Combative Response to Election Losses Startles South Africa
item.media:description: President Jacob Zuma of South Africa in Durban in March. With little explanation, Mr. Zuma recently announced that he would directly oversee the state enterprises that have long been the source of public corruption.
item.description: The country’s governing party has brushed aside calls to replace President Jacob Zuma, raising doubts about another African liberation movement.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: The Health Effects of Growing Old, and Lonely
item.description: Researchers have linked loneliness to physical illness and to functional and cognitive decline. Programs to reach out to the socially isolated are growing in response.
item.dc:creator: KATIE HAFNER

item.title: Letter From Europe: Does the Messaging Service Telegram Take Privacy too Far?
item.media:description: Pavel Durov, a founder of the Telegram messaging application, in 2015. He left his native Russia in 2014 after refusing to give intelligence information about Ukrainian protesters.
item.description: Telegram, favored by the Islamic State because of its formidable privacy controls, is a source of consternation for antiterrorism investigators.
item.dc:creator: CELESTINE BOHLEN
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.S.-Russia Talks on Syria Cease-Fire Stall at G-20
item.media:description: President Obama met President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, on the sidelines of the Group of 20 meeting in Hangzhou, China.
item.description: After meetings on the sidelines with President Vladimir V. Putin failed, President Obama said he had instructed the secretary of state to continue negotiating.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: Sinosphere: Gentler Chicken Slaughter? Chinese Province Thinks It’s Worth a Try
item.media:description: Dead chickens at a slaughterhouse in Shanghai. Shandong Province has issued China’s first guidelines for the more humane killing of chickens.
item.description: New voluntary guidelines in Shandong Province are motivated at least as much by commercial considerations as by concerns for animal welfare.
item.dc:creator: SHAOJIE HUANG

item.title: South Sudan to Allow More U.N. Peacekeepers, but Force Will Be No ‘Panacea’
item.description: An American official warned there was only so much the troops could do in a country beleaguered by civilian massacres, rape and the destruction of food supplies.
item.dc:creator: JEFFREY GETTLEMAN

item.title: London Burns, for the Sake of Art
item.description: A replica of the city’s skyline was set ablaze as part of a festival marking the 350th anniversary of the Great Fire.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Duterte Tells Obama Not to Question Him About Killings
item.description: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte warned President Barack Obama on Monday not to question him about extrajudicial killings, or "son of a bitch I will swear at you" when they meet in Laos during a regional summit.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: North Korea Test-Fires 3 Missiles Toward Japan, Seoul Says
item.media:description: President Park Geun-hye of South Korea at the opening ceremony for the Group of 20 summit meeting in Hangzhou, China, on Sunday.
item.description: The missiles landed in the sea 125 to 155 miles west of Hokkaido, the northernmost of Japan’s main islands, the Japanese Ministry of Defense said.
item.dc:creator: SU-HYUN LEE

item.title: Australian Teenager Sentenced to 10 Years in Jail for Anzac Day Terror Plot
item.description: Sevdet Ramadan Besim, 19, planned to run over and behead a police officer during a parade in Melbourne for the national holiday in 2015.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Sinosphere: Shanghai Violin Competition Celebrates Isaac Stern’s Legacy in China
item.media:description: The Japanese violinist Mayu Kishima was awarded the first prize at the inaugural Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition on Friday.
item.media:credit: Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition
item.description: Mr. Stern’s visit to China, in 1979, is credited with having influenced a generation of young Chinese musicians.
item.dc:creator: AMY QIN
item.category: Shanghai Isaac Stern International Violin Competition

item.title: New Chinese Vessels Seen Near Disputed Reef in South China Sea
item.media:description: A Chinese Coast Guard speedboat as seen from a Philippine vessel near Scarborough Shoal, in the South China Sea, in June.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: The presence of Chinese ships near Scarborough Shoal during a Group of 20 summit meeting unsettled the Philippines, which also claims the reef.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Obama Plays Down Confrontation With China Over His Plane’s Stairs
item.description: China’s handling of the president’s arrival has created a narrative that the Chinese snubbed him. The reality, American officials say, is both simpler and more complicated.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and JANE PERLEZ

item.title: In Hong Kong, Young Protest Leaders Win Seats in Local Elections
item.media:description: Eddie Chu spoke to the news media after winning a seat on Hong Kong’s Legislative Council on Monday.
item.description: Some of the protesters who took part in the large 2014 pro-democracy demonstrations will now wield a small measure of real political power for the first time.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL FORSYTHE and ALAN WONG

item.title: Michel Butor, Experimental French Novelist, Dies at 89
item.media:description: Michel Butor in France in 1989.
item.description: His experiments with narrative and structure in the late 1950s and early ’60s put him at the forefront of the literary trend known as le nouveau roman.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: NICKELSDORF JOURNAL: An Art Exhibit Based on a Migrant Tragedy in Austria Stirs Unease
item.media:description: The border zone in Nickelsdorf, Austria, where asylum seekers took shelter last year.
item.media:credit: Akos Stiller for The New York Times
item.description: A video piece about the white truck in which 71 migrants suffocated last year has divided a border town with a long history of embracing refugees.
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Labour Party Is Poised to Back Jeremy Corbyn Again, Even if Britain Isn’t
item.media:description: Jeremy Corbyn, center, the leader of Britain’s Labour Party, is popular with left-wing party members but has alienated many others.
item.description: The party is expected to re-elect Mr. Corbyn this month despite opposition from its legislators and polls suggesting it will lose badly to the governing Conservatives.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: Nicolas Sarkozy Mounts What He Hopes Is a Comeback in France
item.media:description: Former President Nicolas Sarkozy of France, who is running again, leaving his campaign headquarters in Paris last month.
item.description: In most other political systems he would be a has-been. Yet in a France under terrorist threat, Mr. Sarkozy may be the man of the moment in a presidential race.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER

item.title: Before G-20, Obama Tries to Smooth Things Over With Turkey
item.media:description: Summit leaders posed on Sunday for a “family photo,” with President Obama on one side, and his Turkish counterpart, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, on the other, where he listened to President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.
item.description: He gave his full backing to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and pledged to help bring the plotters of a failed coup to justice.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER

item.title: U.S. Presses for Truce in Syria, With Its Larger Policy on Pause
item.media:description: The rebel-held Bab al-Hadid neighborhood of Aleppo, Syria, in mid-August.
item.description: The Obama administration is engaged in an increasingly desperate effort to broker a deal with Russia for a cease-fire that would halt bombing on Aleppo.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and MARK MAZZETTI
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Raghuram Rajan, India’s Departing Central Banker, Has a New Warning
item.media:description: Raghuram G. Rajan, who ended his three-year term as governor of the Reserve Bank of India on Sunday with a warning about worldwide low interest rates.
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Rajan, whose warnings preceded the global financial crisis, says low interest rates could trap world leaders in inaction.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Far-Right Overtakes Angela Merkel’s Bloc in Her Home State
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany campaigned Saturday in Bad Doberan, a town in her home political state, Mecklenburg-Vorpommern.
item.description: It is the first time in an election in modern Germany that a far-right party has overtaken Ms. Merkel’s bloc of Christian Democrats and the Christian Social Union.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: What in the World: Malta’s Walls Are Covered in Murals, and Street Art Is Covered in Schools
item.media:description: A man relaxed last week near a mural under an overhanging footpath along the coast in Sliema, Malta.
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.description: Most cities denounce, or tolerate, painting on public property. But on this Mediterranean island, the process is not only encouraged, it is funded.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GRIFFITHS

item.title: What in the World: How Some Chinese Men Meet Summer’s Swelter: With Midriff Bare and Bulging
item.media:description: A man near Beijing’s Forbidden City this month rolled up his shirt, a way to keep cool known as the Beijing bikini.
item.media:credit: Gilles Sabrie for The New York Times
item.description: Nothing defines China’s hottest days more than the Beijing Bikini: grown men, without a hint of shame, rolling up shirts to expose often generous bellies.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Letter From a Bahraini Jail
item.description: The United States decision to lift an arms embargo has empowered the regime to intensify its political repressions.
item.dc:creator: NABEEL RAJAB
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Save Gabon From Election Fraud
item.description: When the results finally were announced, a curious set of returns from one province — the incumbent’s — gave him the slimmest of victories over me.
item.dc:creator: JEAN PING

item.title: Editorial Observer: A Bold Attempt to Redefine ‘Dissidence’ in Cuba
item.media:description: Luis Manuel Otero and Yanelis Nuñez Leyva created the Museum of Dissidence in Cuba.
item.media:credit: Hannah Berkeley Cohen for The New York Times
item.description: Through a digital “museum of dissidence,” a Havana couple sets out to remind Cubans that Fidel and Raúl Castro were once dissidents.
item.dc:creator: ERNESTO LONDOÑO
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: How Russia Often Benefits When Julian Assange Reveals the West’s Secrets
item.media:description: Julian Assange looking out from the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in February. Having lived there for four years, he is increasingly isolated.
item.description: American officials say Mr. Assange and WikiLeaks probably have no direct ties to Russian intelligence services. But the agendas of WikiLeaks and the Kremlin have often dovetailed.
item.dc:creator: JO BECKER, STEVEN ERLANGER and ERIC SCHMITT
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Turkish Dam Project Threatens to Submerge Thousands of Years of History
item.media:description: The Turkish town of Hasankeyf will be submerged under 200 feet of water after a hydroelectric dam now under construction is completed.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: A contentious dam project that dates to the 1950s is more than 80 percent complete, and the filling of a reservoir will swamp much of the town of Hasankeyf.
item.dc:creator: TIM ARANGO

item.title: Readers React: Seeing Orange: What Caught Commenters’ Eyes About a Small Syrian Boy in a Big Chair
item.media:description: Omran Daqneesh, 5, was rescued after an airstrike in the Syrian city of Aleppo.
item.description: Our Photo Editors’ Notebook on what made the image of Omran Daqneesh stand out inspired many readers to share their thoughts.
item.dc:creator: INSIDER STAFF
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT

item.title: Notebook: How Many Guns Did the U.S. Lose Track of in Iraq and Afghanistan? Hundreds of Thousands.
item.media:description: Iraqi soldiers after receiving new rifles from U.S. forces in Baghdad in May 2007.
item.description: A new study shows how the American military failed at the soldier’s most basic responsibility: keeping track of firearms.
item.dc:creator: C. J. CHIVERS
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
